subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etyl}}
{{liushu|p}} – side view of a standing man, highlighting the arms and legs. Compare {{zh-l|*大}}.

subSections.title: Etymology 1
subSections.text:
{{zh-forms|alt=亻-component,𠆢-component,⺈-component,儿-component,几,𠔽,𤯔}}
{{unknown|zh}}.

{{zh-ref|Sagart (1999)}} relates it to {{cog|bo|ཉེན||relative}}, from {{m|bo|ཉེ||near}} + nominalizing suffix ''-n''; if so, from {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*s-naːj ~ *s-nej||near}}.

{{zh-ref|Schuessler (2007)}} proposes two etymologies:
* Same etymon as {{och-l|仁|to be kind; to be good}}, from {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*s/k-niŋ||heart; brain; mind}}. The semantic association of {{lang|zh|仁}} with {{lang|zh|人}} was somewhat late, in [[Mencius]]' time; later on, {{lang|zh|仁}} would be usually interpreted as "humane, acting like a human being".
** If so, semantically parallel with {{cog|bo|སེམས་ཅན||living being, human, animal|lit=possessor of mind}}; and {{cog|la|animalis||living, having soul}} from {{m|la|anima||soul}}.
* Related to {{cog|mkh-pro|*ɲaʔ ~ *ɲah||person}} with a nominalizing suffix ''-n'', possibly from the auto-ethnonym of a hostile, possibly {{w|Austroasiatic languages|Austroasiatic-speaking}}, {{w|Yueshi culture|eastern}} people, whom the Sinitic-speaking {{w|Shang dynasty|Shang}} referred to as {{och-l|人方|id=1,1}}.

subSections.title: Etymology 2
subSections.text:
{{zh-forms|alt=儂,𠆧}}
The Min native word for “person”; used as a replacement character for {{zh-l|儂|tr=-}}. Use of {{lang|zh|人}} is [http://twblg.dict.edu.tw/holodict_new/iongji/pdf/annesia325pdf.pdf recommended] by Taiwan's Ministry of Education.
